name: 3-(4-methylsulfonylbenzoyl)propionic acid
Reason: Starting with benzene as a basic unit, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The presence of a sulfone group (SO2) attached to the benzene ring tends to increase the melting point due to the introduction of polar characteristics and possible intermolecular hydrogen bonding; this could add roughly +80 °C. A carboxylic acid group (-COOH) typically raises the melting point significantly because of the potential for strong hydrogen bonding; this could contribute with an addition of roughly +70 °C. The ketone functional group (C=O) within the acyl side chain could raise the melting point by +10 °C due to polar interactions. Lastly, a methyl group attached to the benzene ring could add about +5 °C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces. Summing up all these effects: 5.5 (benzene) + 80 (sulfonyl) + 70 (carboxylic acid) + 10 (ketone) + 5 (methyl) gives a predicted total increase.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C.
- Carboxylic acid group: +100 °C (due to strong hydrogen bonding and dimer formation).
- Methylsulfonyl group: +30 °C (due to its electron-withdrawing nature and potential for dipole-dipole interactions).
- Conjugated system: +20 °C (due to increased rigidity and planarity of the molecule).
- Propionic acid group: +10 °C (due to the additional carboxylic acid group which can form hydrogen bonds).
